predictions.text: The U.S. Department of Homeland Security will experience a lapse in appropriations that triggers a partial shutdown lasting at least 24 consecutive hours.
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if DHS/OMB/Congressional notices or at least two major outlets report a DHS funding lapse with shutdown procedures in effect for >=24 consecutive hours before funding is restored; otherwise NO.
evidence: Recent reporting highlights elevated DHS shutdown risk amid budget brinkmanship.
DHS operations include many non-exempt functions that typically require shutdown planning during funding lapses.
monitoring_signals: Congressional action (CR/appropriations) specifically funding DHS
DHS contingency planning memos or public statements
House/Senate procedural votes and whip counts near funding deadlines
predictions.rationale: Political brinkmanship raises lapse risk, but CRs are common; requiring a >=24-hour lapse keeps this from triggering on near-miss funding gaps.

predictions.text: FERC will issue a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NOPR) or formal policy proposal that explicitly addresses cost allocation and/or interconnection requirements for new large-load (>=50 MW) data centers or similar high-density loads.
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if FERC publishes (Federal Register or FERC docket) a NOPR/policy statement proposing rule changes that explicitly mention large loads/data centers (or equivalent) and cost allocation/interconnection obligations; otherwise NO.
evidence: Public White House messaging suggests shifting grid/energy costs toward data-center developers.
Grid constraints from data-center growth are increasingly salient for regulators and ISOs.
monitoring_signals: FERC technical conferences or dockets on large load / interconnection / cost allocation
ISO/RTO filings requesting guidance or rule changes
DOE or White House statements on grid cost responsibility for data centers
predictions.rationale: Regulatory pressure is rising, but translating concern into a formal FERC proposal within 2026 is uncertain.

predictions.text: OpenAI will announce a consumer distribution partnership in India with a major telecom or handset OEM that bundles a paid ChatGPT tier (or equivalent) into customer plans, explicitly stating the bundle includes a paid subscription.
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if OpenAI or the partner (e.g., Reliance Jio, Bharti Airtel, major handset OEM) publishes a press release/blog stating a plan bundle includes a paid ChatGPT subscription/credit; otherwise NO.
evidence: OpenAI leadership cites very large weekly active usage in India, indicating a major distribution opportunity.
India is seeing increased AI-infrastructure activity, suggesting intensified competition for user monetization.
monitoring_signals: Telco plan announcements mentioning ChatGPT/OpenAI
OpenAI India hiring, partnerships, or localized product launches
App store pricing/promotions tied to telecom billing
predictions.rationale: High usage makes bundling attractive, but commercial terms and regulatory/partner alignment add friction.

predictions.text: An India-based AI compute / data-center platform startup will announce an equity or debt financing round with total new committed capital of at least $750 million (USD equivalent) in a single round.
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if a company headquartered in India and primarily focused on AI compute/data centers announces a single financing round (equity and/or debt) totaling >=$750M USD equivalent, confirmed by the company and at least one major outlet; otherwise NO.
evidence: Recent large financings are occurring as India pushes to build domestic AI compute amid power constraints.
monitoring_signals: Large debt facilities or project financing announcements for Indian AI/data-center platforms
PE infrastructure funds entering Indian compute (term sheets, exclusivity reports)
Government policy incentives affecting data-center capex economics
predictions.rationale: Momentum is strong, but size threshold is high and dependent on power availability and lender risk appetite.

predictions.text: Japan National Tourism Organization (JNTO) will report mainland China visitor arrivals to Japan down at least 15% year-over-year in at least one monthly release.
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if any JNTO monthly statistics release dated by 2026-09-30 shows mainland China visitor arrivals to Japan with y/y change <= -15%; otherwise NO.
evidence: Recent reporting indicates Japan–China tensions are weighing on tourism demand.
monitoring_signals: JNTO monthly inbound tourism releases
China travel advisories and airline capacity changes on China–Japan routes
High-frequency hotel occupancy/flight booking indicators
predictions.rationale: Tourism is sensitive to diplomatic tensions and sentiment; a -15% print is plausible but not guaranteed.

predictions.text: Aggregate U.S. spot Bitcoin ETFs will record net outflows of at least $2.5 billion over a rolling 30-day window.
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if a widely cited tracker (e.g., Bloomberg, BitMEX Research, ETF issuers) shows cumulative net flows across U.S.-listed spot Bitcoin ETFs <= -$2.5B over any contiguous 30-day period ending by 2026-06-30; otherwise NO.
evidence: Recent selloff reduced ETF inflows, signaling vulnerability to a larger reversal if risk-off persists.
monitoring_signals: Daily ETF flow data across major spot Bitcoin ETFs
BTC realized volatility and drawdowns
Funding rates / futures basis and broader risk sentiment indicators
predictions.rationale: Flows can swing quickly during drawdowns; threshold is large but achievable under sustained risk-off.

predictions.text: Warner Bros. Discovery and Paramount Global will publicly confirm (via SEC filing or press release) that they have entered exclusive negotiations or signed a non-binding term sheet/MOU for a potential transaction.
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if either company files an 8-K (or equivalent) or issues a press release stating exclusivity or a signed term sheet/MOU for a transaction with the other; routine media rumors without such confirmation do not count.
evidence: Recent reporting suggests renewed consideration of talks, reflecting continued consolidation pressure in streaming/media.
monitoring_signals: 8-K filings, investor presentations, and earnings-call disclosures
Regulatory/antitrust signaling around large media combinations
Debt-market conditions affecting transaction financing
predictions.rationale: Consolidation incentives are real, but governance, valuation, and regulatory risk make formal exclusivity/term sheets uncertain.

predictions.text: The European Commission will publish an implementing act, delegated act, or formal guidance document that specifies reporting/recordkeeping requirements for the EU ban on destruction of unsold apparel and footwear.
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if the European Commission (or Official Journal) publishes a document explicitly detailing compliance reporting/recordkeeping for the destruction ban on unsold apparel/footwear by 2026-12-31; otherwise NO.
evidence: EU has adopted rules restricting destruction of unsold clothes and shoes, implying follow-on compliance specifications.
monitoring_signals: Official Journal / Commission updates under the relevant regulation
Consultations with industry and member-state implementation timelines
Retail trade association compliance briefings
predictions.rationale: New bans typically require operational guidance; timing depends on administrative prioritization and consultation.

predictions.text: At least one major U.S. auto industry group or automaker (e.g., Alliance for Automotive Innovation or a top-10 OEM) will file a lawsuit challenging the EPA decision to end regulatory crediting for stop-start vehicle technology.
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if a complaint/petition for review is filed (e.g., D.C. Circuit) explicitly challenging EPA’s stop-start credit policy change, confirmed by court docket and reported by at least one major legal/trade outlet; otherwise NO.
evidence: EPA policy change affects automaker compliance economics by removing credit for an incremental efficiency technology.
monitoring_signals: EPA Federal Register notices and effective dates
Auto industry public comments and intent-to-sue statements
New court filings in relevant circuits
predictions.rationale: Economic impact creates litigation incentive, but industry may prefer lobbying/negotiation over court action.

predictions.text: Canada will award a defense procurement contract with a stated value of at least C$1.0 billion to a prime contractor headquartered outside the United States, explicitly framed as part of procurement diversification or domestic/ally industrial policy.
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if the Government of Canada announces a defense contract >=C$1.0B (press release or procurement notice) where the prime is non-U.S.-headquartered and official language explicitly cites diversification/industrial policy (or equivalent) as a motivation; otherwise NO.
evidence: Recent reporting indicates Canada is signaling defense spending increases won’t automatically flow to U.S. arms makers.
monitoring_signals: Canadian DND/PSPC procurement announcements and tender outcomes
Statements on defense-industrial strategy and allied sourcing
Major program updates (air, naval, air defense, ISR) with vendor selection milestones
predictions.rationale: Stated intent to diversify increases odds, but procurement cycles and U.S. interoperability constraints can limit near-term awards.
